page.text: 1.1. Roll Call
1.2. Pledge of Allegiance to Our Flag
3.1. Regular Meeting of September 22, 2014.
4.1. Appearance by Mankato Area Fair Trade Town Initiative
representatives
5. Consent Calendar
5.1. Motion to waive the rental fees for use of Sibley Park for the YWCA of
Mankato Girls on the Run event to be held on April 25, 2015.

text.b: NOTE: All items listed under the Consent Calendar will be enacted by one motion.
There will be no separate discussion of these items. If a Council Member wishes to
discuss any of these items, they may ask that the item be removed from the Consent
Calendar. Removed items(s) will be discussed and acted upon by separate motion.

page.text: 5.2. Motion approving on-sale intoxicating liquor license (Class B), Sunday
liquor, non-enclosed premise (patio), and 2 a.m. closing for M, M, and
M, Inc., DBA Jonny B’s on the Plaza, 12 Civic Center Plaza, #1675
(current location of Mum’s the Word).
5.3. Motion authorizing the City Manager to enter into an interagency
agreement with the Minnesota Department of Employment and
Economic Development’s State Services for the Blind (SSB) division
for the purpose of facilitating the Radio Talking Book (RTB) broadcast
for Mankato.
5.4. Resolution approving premise permit application by the St. Clair Fire
Relief Association to conduct lawful gambling at The Bicker inn, 100
East Walnut Street.
5.5. Resolution authorizing the City Manager to accept bid to purchase
used fire rescue apparatus.
5.6. Motion approving the Preliminary Plat of Country Club Estates No. 20
with conditions, Outlot A, Country Club Estates No. 19; by request of
Hiniker Homes.
5.7. Resolution granting Conditional Use Permit to allow storage units in
the B-2, Highway Commercial District, 1721 Madison Avenue; by
request of Amerco Real Estate/U-Haul Company of Southern
Minnesota.
5.8. Resolution approving Final Plat of Campus Townhomes and
Resolution approving Planned Unit Development, Lot 1, Block 1,
University Park Subdivision No. 6 and Outlots C, D and G, Oak Marsh
Subdivision; by request of Growth Holdings, LLC and Campus
Cottages, LLC.
5.9. Consideration of bids on Capital Improvement Project Number 88060;
Premier Drive Signal System.
5.10. Resolution authorizing the City Manager to enter into Supplemental
Agreement for License Audit Number 185425 with the Union Pacific
Railroad Company covering a 27-inch sewer pipeline crossing
Railroad property at Mile Post 83.82 located within the municipal limits
of the City of Mankato.
5.11. Resolution authorizing the City Manager to enter into Supplemental
Agreement for License Audit Number NWE197 with the Union Pacific
Railroad Company covering a 12-inch water pipeline crossing Railroad
property at Mile Post 83.82 located within the municipal limits of the
City of Mankato.
5.12. Resolution authorizing the City Manager to enter into a grant
agreement with the Minnesota Pollution Control Agency for a pilot
project on Ultra Low Phosphorus Removal.
5.13. Resolution authorizing the City Manager to execute an extension of
the State of Minnesota Hazardous Materials/CAT contract.
5.14. Set October 27, 2014, as date of public hearing on Ordinances
establishing franchise fees for Gas and Electric.
5.15. Set October 27, 2014, as date of public hearing for the Ordinance
amending the South Front Street Special Service District.
5.16. Set November 10, 2014, as date of public hearing for the 2015 Public
Housing Agency Plan (PHA) for the Mankato Economic Development
Authority.
6.1. Resolution annexing property per Joint Resolution for Orderly
Annexation; Resolution approving Final Plat of Fern Subdivision; and
Ordinance rezoning Lot 1, Block 1, Fern Subdivision from T,
Transition, to B-3, Highway Commercial District; by request of Haefner
Children, LLP.
6.2. Ordinance amending Chapter 3 of the Mankato City Code relating to
refuse and recycling.
7.1. Motion approving Preliminary Plat of Dancing Waters Subdivision with
conditions, Part of Section 21, Mankato Township (south of Glen Ellen
Estates and west of Country Woods Estates); by request of Orion
Development.
8.1. Resolution authorizing the City Manger to accept COPS Hiring
Program Grant for two Police Officer positions under the 2014 COPS
Hiring Program.
9.1. Planning Commission Meeting minutes from September 24, 2014.
View all city committee meetings at:
10.1. Regular Council Meeting, October 27, 2014, 6 p.m., Mankato Room
(with Work Session to follow)
10.2. Work Session, November 3, 2014, 6 p.m., Minnesota River Room
10.3. Regular Council Meeting, November 10, 2014, 7 p.m., Mankato Room
(possible Work Session to follow)
Those wishing to speak must state their name and address for the record
after they reach the podium.
12. Adjournment
Mankato City Council
Regular Meeting
September 22, 2014 – 6:00 p.m.
IGC – Mankato Room
A Regular Meeting of the Mankato City Council was conducted on September 22,
2014 at 6:00 p.m. with Mayor Pro Tem Frederick presiding. Council Members
Karen Foreman, Jason Mattick, Mark Frost, and Tamra Rovney were present.
Also present were City Manager Patrick Hentges, Deputy City Manager Tanya
Ange, Community Development Director Paul Vogel, Housing Coordinator Patty
Ziegler, Co-Interim City Attorney Linda Hilligoss and Executive Assistant Renae
Kopischke. Following roll call, the Pledge of Allegiance was given.
(2.1) Mayor Pro Tem Frederick requested any corrections or additions to the
agenda. Mr. Frost moved to approve the agenda as amended; removal of 5.10.
Ms. Rovney seconded the motion
. With all members voting in favor, the motion
carried.
(3.1) Mayor Pro Tem Frederick requested any corrections or additions to the
minutes of the Regular Meeting of September 8, 2014. Mr. Frost moved and Ms.
Foreman seconded a motion to approve the minutes as written
. With all
members voting in favor, the motion carried.
(4.1) Recognition of 2015 Calendar Photo Contest Winners
Mayor Pro Tem Frederick requested any corrections or additions to the Consent
Calendar. Mr. Mattick pulled item 5.4 and Mayor Pro Tem Frederick pulled item
5.12. Mr. Frost moved and Ms. Rovney seconded a motion to approve the
Consent Calendar as amended
. The motion carried unanimously.
The following items were approved on the Consent Calendar:
(5.1) Motion appointing Council Member Christopher Frederick to the Advisory
Council for Community Education and Recreation.
(5.2) Motion approving temporary on-sale intoxicating liquor license for Mankato
Curling Club, 600 Hope Street, for an event occurring (fundraiser) on October 25,
2014, from 2 p.m. to 5 p.m.
(5.3) Motion approving license to encroach for existing retaining wall at 229 West
Pleasant Street; by request of Leslie Graham.
(5.5) Resolution appointing Election Judges for the 2014 General Election.
(5.6) Resolution approving the Consent to Change Control (Charter
Communications, Inc./New Charter, Inc. Transaction).
(5.7) Resolution authorizing Mankato International Association of Firefighters
(IAFF) Local 579 to conduct off-duty fundraising “Fill the Boot” drive to benefit the
Muscular Dystrophy Association (MDA) on September 29, 30, and October 1,
2014 from 3 p.m. to 7 p.m.
(5.8) Resolution directing parking control; install no parking signs beginning at
the intersection of West Elm Street and Maple Street continuing 72-feet north
along Maple Street and 38-feet east along West Elm Street.
(5.9) Resolution approving an Annexation Petition under Joint resolution for
Orderly Annexation with Mankato Township – northwest quadrant of the
intersection of Country Club Drive and Augusta Drive (100 Country Club Drive);
by request of Josh Kelley.
(5.11) Set October 13, 2014, as date of public hearing for Ordinance rezoning
property from T, Transition, to B-3, Highway Business District (Lot 1, Block 1,
Fern Subdivision); by request of Haefner Children.
(5.4) Mr. Mattick pulled the Resolution adopting the provisional license and policy
for food trucks and carts in the public right-of-way. He inquired as to why it was a
policy versus an ordinance.
Mr. Hentges responded that there are review opportunities in establishing a
policy which allow more flexibility to evaluate and make revisions if needed.
Mr. Mattick expressed concerns regarding limiting the hours of operation. Mr.
Hentges replied that the city looked at other cities and most had time restrictions.
He indicated that staff also felt there could be some concerns with the activities in
the downtown core, including moving people out of the area at closing, if a time
restriction wasn’t implemented.
Melo Mendez, 1525 Tullamore Street, owner of Mazatlan, mentioned he would
like to see the time restriction extended.
Brief discussion took place on the time restriction. Mr. Frederick supported a time
restriction of 2 a.m. and Mr. Mattick felt that a time restriction shouldn’t be put in
place, as there would be a lot of potential business after 2 a.m.
Pierre Sadaka, 70 Jayro Court, wondered if the fee would be charged per event
or annually. Mr. Hentges replied, annually.
Mr. Hentges noted that the Civic Center has a selection process in place for
vendors in conjunction with events at Riverfront Park. He mentioned that food
trucks would need to be 200 feet from events no matter the location.
Ms. Foreman stated that she was comfortable starting with a time restriction of
midnight and then reviewing the policy in the future with possibility of extending
the time.
Ms. Rovney indicated she was supportive of the proposed time limit of midnight.
Mr. Mattick moved to approve the Resolution adopting the provisional license
and policy for food trucks and carts in the public right-of-way with no time limit
Motion failed for lack of a second.
Mr. Frost moved and Ms. Foreman seconded a motion to approve the Resolution
adopting the provisional license and policy for food trucks and carts in the public
right-of-way as presented
. The motion carried four to one with Mr. Frederick
voting against.
(5.12) Mr. Frederick pulled the Set October 13, 2014, as date of public hearing
for Ordinance amending Chapter 3 of the Mankato City Code relating to refuse
and recycling. He requested that the storage of carts be further clarified.
It was noted that some residents don’t have garages which would make inside
storage during winter months more difficult.
Mr. Frost moved and Ms. Rovney seconded a motion to approve the date of
public hearing for Ordinance amending Chapter 3. Motion carried unanimously.
(6.1) Mr. Hentges presented the Ordinance rezoning property from T, Transition,
to R-1, One-Family Dwelling District (former Applewood Restaurant Property –
11 Telemark Drive); by request of Harry Musser. He noted that the rezoning
matches the zoning of abutting properties in the area, including the homes on
Telemark Drive.
Mayor Pro Tem Frederick opened the public hearing. There being no one wishing
to speak, Mayor Pro Tem Frederick closed the public hearing.
Ms. Foreman moved and Ms. Rovney seconded a motion to approve the
Ordinance rezoning property from T, Transition to R-1, One-Family Dwelling
District (former Applewood Restaurant Property – 11 Telemark Drive)
. With all
members voting in favor, the motion carried.
(6.2) Mr. Vogel stated that back in May 2010, the Council adopted the 2010-2014
Consolidated Plan for utilization of the Community Development Block Grant
(CDBG) funding. The plan detailed how the funding would be used in
conformance with CDBG guidelines. He indicated that the fourth year ended on
June 30, 2014. Mr. Vogel explained that federal regulations that govern the
CDBG program require two public hearings every year. The purpose of the first
hearing is to review the Action Plan for the coming year, which was held on May
12, 2014. The purpose of the second hearing is to review the program
performance for the previous year, which is the subject of the requested action.
Mr. Vogel indicated that the performance for the previous year is summarized in
a standardized format referred to as the Consolidated Annual Performance
Evaluation Report (CAPER).
Ms. Ziegler was available to answer any questions.
Mayor Pro Tem Frederick opened the public hearing. There being no one wishing
to speak, Mayor Pro Tem Frederick closed the public hearing.
Ms. Rovney moved and Ms. Foreman seconded a motion to approve the
submittal of the Consolidated Annual Performance Evaluation Report (CAPER)
for the Community Development Block Grant (CDBG) Program
. The motion
carried unanimously.
(6.3) Mr. Vogel provided an overview of the Ordinance amending Section 10.87
(Sign Ordinance) relating to wall signage, ground pylon signs, and mobile signs.
He explained that the proposal would add vehicles and trailers designed or
utilized for mobile signage purposes to the existing list of prohibited signage;
however, this would not impact work trucks, delivery vehicles, buses, or other
vehicles where signage upon the vehicle is secondary to the vehicles primary
intended use. Additionally, the proposal would modify wall signage standards to
allow for additional wall signage options for buildings in all non-residential zoning
districts.
Mayor Pro Tem Frederick opened the public hearing. There being no one wishing
to speak, Mayor Pro Tem Frederick closed the public hearing.
Ms. Foreman moved and Ms. Rovney seconded a motion to approve the
Ordinance amending Section 10.87 (Sign Ordinance) relating to wall signage,
ground pylon signs, and mobile signs
. The motion carried unanimously.
(6.4) Ms. Ange reported on the franchise agreement renewals with CenterPoint,
Xcel, and BENCO. She noted that staff continues to negotiate the Charter
franchise and expects to have an agreement completed after the CCTV transition
to Bethany.
Ms. Ange explained that even though street lighting maintenance is not a part of
the Xcel or BENCO franchise agreements, franchisees and staff have worked to
ensure standard locations are consistent between databases, which aids in
efficient response time of repairs.
Ms. Ange stated that there were not substantial changes within the CenterPoint
agreement other than updates reflecting changes with the Public Utilities
Commission and the Xcel and BENCO agreements were modified to ensure
consistency between the two electric franchises. It was noted that when the
Greater Minnesota Gas franchise expires it will be recommended that the same
approach is taken, which is supported by the franchisees.
Ms. Ange also reported on the Ordinances establishing Franchise Fees for Gas
and Electric. She mentioned that the fee increases were discussed within the
budget and that through negotiations and discussions a flat rate fee was
recommended.
Ms. Foreman stated that the fees are placed in the General Fund, but wondered
if part of the fees end up in the Street Fund. Ms. Ange responded that the fees
are placed in the General Fund to cover maintenance and offset right-of-way
expenditures. She noted that reconstructions were not included.
Mr. Frederick felt the fee increases were significant; he wondered why they were
so aggressive. Ms. Ange stated that when the franchise fees were adopted the
city was required to discontinue collection of permit fees for disruption in the
right-of-way from the franchisees.
Mr. Hentges pointed out that the growth of the city was also a factor and that
management of right-of-ways was becoming more challenging.
Ms. Foreman indicated that the franchise fees were done on a long term basis
and that all properties pay for the service and the cost is spread evenly.
Mr. Frost indicated that he struggled too with the fee increases.
Mayor Pro Tem Frederick opened the public hearing. There being no one wishing
to speak, Mayor Pro Tem Frederick closed the public hearing.
Ms. Foreman moved and Ms. Rovney seconded a motion to approve the
Ordinances adopting Franchises for CenterPoint, Xcel, and BENCO
. The motion
carried unanimously.
It was noted that there is a ninety (90) day publication period that must occur;
thus, if the ordinances establishing fees fails changes will need to be looked at
within the 2015 budget.
Ms. Rovney moved and Ms. Foreman seconded a motion to approve the
Ordinances establishing Franchise Fees for Gas and Electric
. The motion failed
three to two with Mr. Frost and Mayor Pro Tem Frederick voting against.
(7.1) Mr. Hentges presented a request by Matthias Leyrer and Ben Lundsten to
use Cherry Street Plaza on October 10 for “Pixels in the Plaza”. He stated that
the proposal includes placement of two screens projecting video games that
people will be able to watch and participate in if they wish. The event will be held
from 8 p.m. until Midnight. Mr. Hentges covered the requirements associated with
the event.
Ms. Rovney moved and Mr. Frost seconded a motion to approve the use of
Cherry Street Plaza for “Pixels in the Plaza”
. With all members voting in favor,
the motion carried.
(7.2) Mr. Hentges reported on the Resolution authorizing the Mayor and City
Manager to execute Grant Agreement for Civic Center Renovation and
Expansion. He indicated that during the 2014 legislative session, $14.5 million of
general fund money was appropriated to the city to undertake the renovation and
expansion of the Civic Center. The funds will be managed through the Minnesota
Department of Employment and Economic Development (DEED). He explained
that matching funds of at least $14.5 million must be provided by the city and the
appropriation language allows previously incurred costs related to the arena
improvements to be counted toward the match requirement. The source of the
matching funds is the local option sales tax revenue, which has been authorized
for such expenditures.
Ms. Rovney moved and Ms. Foreman seconded a motion to approve the
Resolution authorizing the Mayor and City Manager to execute Grant Agreement
for Civic Center Renovation and Expansion
. With all members voting in favor, the
motion carried.
(8.1) Multi-Modal Meeting minutes from July 22, 2014 were received; no action
required.
Mr. Frost mentioned Mr. Freyberg’s concerns regarding the noise from events at
Riverfront Park. Mr. Hentges indicated that the concerns would be discussed at
the Intergovernmental Committee Meeting on November 4.
Ms. Foreman requested that street lighting standards be further discussed at a
Work Session in January, February, or March. She mentioned that several
residents have expressed that they would like additional lighting.
Mayor Pro Tem Frederick reminded the Council of the following upcoming
meetings:
(9.1) Work Session, September 29, 2014, 6 p.m., Minnesota River Room
(9.2) Work Session, October 6, 2014, 6 p.m., Minnesota River Room
(9.3) Regular Council Meeting, October 13, 2014, 7 p.m., Mankato Room
(possible Work Session to follow)
No one spoke.
There being no further business before the Council, Ms. Foreman moved and Mr.
Frost seconded a motion to adjourn
. With all members voting in favor, the
meeting was adjourned at 7:30 p.m.
Minutes Approved.
Mayor Pro Tem Frederick
ATTEST:
Renae Kopischke
Executive Secretary

text.b: Mankato Area Fair Trade Town Initiative
from the Fair Trade Town Declaration
by the Mankato City Council, October 24, 2011

page.text: City Council Meeting, October 13, 2014
A.
INTRODUCTION
Fair Trade
Fair Trade is a market-based approach to combating poverty in the Global South, promoting an
alternative to dependency on aid. Through the Fair Trade system the lives of family farmers and
workers in 70 countries are enriched, the natural environment is supported, sustainable
development strategies are pursued, women are empowered and a greater degree of family
financial security is achieved.
American consumers can distinguish Fair Trade products by four product logos (left block
below) which denote that a product has been produced under Fair Trade conditions. The WFTO
and FTF (on the right) comprise business networks committed to work on Fair Trade principles
throughout the supply chain.
Fair Trade
USA
Fairtrade
Internat’l
Institute for
Marketecology
Lat. Amer-Carib.
Small Producers
World Fair
Trade Org’n
US business
association
MAFTTI
MAFTTI is a non-profit registered with the State of Minnesota. A 501(c)3 federal application is
pending. MAFTTI is part of a national Fair Trade Towns Campaign that started in 2006 when
Media, PA, became the first US Fair Trade Town. Currently there are 35 Fair Trade Towns in the
USA, ranging in size from Chicago, IL to Buena Vista, CO. When Mankato became the 25
th
in
the USA there were 1,014 Fair Trade Towns in 22 countries (of which 517 were in the UK,
where the idea started in 2000). Now there are 1,536 Fair Trade Towns in 24 countries.
The work of MAFTTI is guided by a Steering Committee that is recognized by the national office
of Fair Trade Campaigns, an umbrella entity that oversees the development of advocacy on Fair
Trade in Colleges, Universities, Schools and Religious Congregations as well as Towns.
After its formation in mid-2009 MAFTTI worked to fulfill the criteria of the Fair Trade Towns
campaign with respect to
o The availability of Fair Trade products in local stores, cafés and other venues.
o The use of Fair Trade products in local organizations, such as places of worship,
schools, hospitals and offices.
o Attracting local media attention and visible public support.
o Engaging the community.
MAFTTI and the Mankato City Council
MAFTTI made its first presentation to the Council shortly after it was formed and a second in
April 2010. Subsequently, on May 8, 2010, a Proclamation was issued whereby “the Mayor and
City Councilors of the City of Mankato do hereby proclaim that the City of Mankato supports
the efforts of the Mankato Area Fair Trade Town Initiative”. In October 2010, January 2011
and July 2011 MAFTTI submitted progress reports. On September 26, 2011 MAFTTI participated
in a Working Session with the City Council which led to the Fair Trade Town Declaration being
passed unanimously at the Council meeting on October 24, 2011.
B.
MANKATO - FAIR TRADE TOWN
Keeping an eye on the wider world
MAFTTI’s participation in a number of Fair Trade ventures outside Mankato has provided it
with experience and perspectives that strengthen the telling of the story of Fair Trade and its
impact on producers and farmers in the Global South.
5th International Fair
Trade Towns Conference
Malmo,
Sweden
Paul & Arlene Renshaw
March 28-April 4, 2012
Visit to Fair Trade
producers – Fair Trade
Towns USA delegation
Dominican
Republic
Margo Druschel
Fair Trade Campaigns
Conference
Chicago, IL
Paul & Arlene Renshaw
Margo Druschel
FTT-USA Visit to Mexico
Oaxaca &
Chiapas
Jane Dow
April 5, 2014
Fair Trade Campaigns
Regional Gathering
Milwaukee, WI
Margo Druschel (and
Emily Kracht, Loyola)
In addition MAFTTI has organized two significant visits to the Mankato area:
Jorge Restrepo & Felipe Zapata
Colombian FT banana producers
October 18-21, 2012
Kelsey Timmerman
Author, “Where Am I Wearing?”
September 11-12, 2014
Margo
Druschel
visited
FT
producers in the DR, April 2012
Felipe
Zapata
(Colombia)
visited Pat Hentges, Oct. 2012
Kelsey Timmerman and Fair Trade
Fashion Show, September 2014
Post-Declaration program
Following the Fair Trade Town Declaration, the MAFTTI Steering Committee identified a
number of annual targets so as to continue the process of fostering deeper and broader
awareness of Fair Trade within the area.
Product availability
At the time of the Declaration MAFTTI pointed to 15 retail outlets that stocked Fair Trade
products. This number has not risen. There have been some closures (mainly of small
enterprises) while some well-established chains have started to include one or two Fair Trade
products on their shelves. However, the number of Fair Trade product categories available in
local stores has risen from 15 to 20 and choices of Fair Trade coffee available in supermarkets
have increased three-fold. Since April 2012 Fair Trade bananas have been available (in Cub
West) as a specific result of the MAFTTI’s advocacy with SuperValu.
Institutional usage of Fair Trade products
MAFTTI is not a church project though its primary constituency has, since the beginning, been
found in a number of churches in Mankato. MAFTTI can point to nine places of worship in
Mankato that are institutionally committed to Fair Trade: Centenary UMC; First
Congregational/UCC; First Presbyterian; Hope Interfaith Center; three Lutheran churches
(Bethlehem, Christ the King and Grace); St. John’s Episcopal; Unitarian Universalist Fellowship.
A few more use Fair Trade coffee at least – notably St.John the Baptist Catholic and Hosanna
Lutheran. Jazzman’s Café at MSU and Mayo Clinic (both through Sodexo), the YMCA and Twin
Rivers Council for the Arts also provide Fair Trade Certified coffee. The process of broadening
the base of support for Fair Trade among other community groups and institutions continues
as, for example, with the YWCA, VINE and in the business sector.
Very recently, on October 1, the start of Fair Trade Month, the School Sisters of Notre Dame at
Good Counsel made a “Declaration of Commitment to Fair Trade”, a step which MAFTTI hopes
will prove to be a significant contribution to building the Fair Trade movement in the Mankato
area.
Fair Trade in the media
o MAFTTI leadership has been able to go on air at KTOE radio at least twice per year and
occasionally on KMSU.
o Articles in the Free Press by or featuring MAFTTI numbered 3 in 2009, 5 in 2010, 7 in 2011,
5 in 2012, 1 in 2013 and 3 so far in 2014.
Fund-raising and Fair Trade education
MAFTTI has had considerable success when special fundraising events have been organized.
This is the record from its inception:
Event
Date
Speaker or program
Tickets
Dinner
Alicia Ranney, (Dir. MN Fair Trade Coalition)
Dinner
John de Graaf (film-maker - “Buyer, Be Fair”)
Red Sky Lounge
Music and Fair Trade education
Bananamania
Jorge Restrepo and Felipe Zapata (Colombia)
Fair Trade Tea
April 28, 2013
Four kinds of Fair Trade tea, with edibles
Mexico Night
Jane Dow (on Oaxaca and Chiapas)
th
Anniv.- Peru
Joyce Bucklin (10K Villages, Mountain Lake)
Fashion Show
Kelsey Timmerman & Mata Traders clothes
Fair Trade focus times
o On World Fair Trade Day (second Saturday in May), MAFTTI has mounted display boards in
coffee shops and offered Fair Trade coffee at one or two supermarkets.
o For Fair Trade Month (October) MAFTTI has provided exhibition material for display cases
at Blue Earth County Library, Mankato.
o At Halloween MAFTTI has promoted ‘Reverse Trick or Treating’ – Fair Trade chocolate
pieces handed out with cards summarizing the merits of buying Fair Trade - 2,200 in 2009,
Other features of MAFTTI’s program
o Campus & Community Fair, MSU: One morning, late August-early September, 2010-2014.
o Mankato Area International Festival: One Sunday in mid-April, 2010-2014.
o Mankato Farmers’ Market on Saturdays, 8.00-12 noon: A Fair Trade literature and sample
products table was set up most intensively in 2010-2011 in the build-up of support for a
Fair Trade Town Declaration. In 2012 and 2013 MAFTTI was present monthly (May-August)
and in 2014 only twice, partly because of the change of location to a smaller site.
o Mankato Marathon, October 2012: MAFTTI provided Fair Trade banana bites for passing
runners, with the cooperation of Cub West.
o North Mankato Fun Days Parade, 2010-2014 (second Saturday in July) with Carmen
Miranda as the focus. (2010-2011 the Carmen Miranda float also appeared at the MSU
Homecoming Parade.)
o Sustainability Expo, MSU, April 5, 2014: MAFTTI literature table for one-day event.
Connections with formal education
MAFTTI has, from the start, been interested in fostering Fair Trade education among young
people. This has been expressed through
o Developing curriculum materials for testing/use in a number of grades in the ISD77 system.
o Supporting, as far as possible, student initiatives on Fair Trade taken at MSU.
o Taking opportunities to work with MSU faculty interested in Fair Trade – including
responding to an invitation to give the Kessel Memorial Lecture in March 2012.
o Sharing experience of Fair Trade with business and sociology students at MSU.
o Introducing Fair Trade to an economics class at Bethany Lutheran College.
o Encouraging the Fair Trade work at Loyola when it became known in 2010 and celebrating
the success when Loyola became the first K-12 Fair Trade School in the USA in May 2012.
o Leading classes at Loyola following visits to Fair Trade producers in the Dominican Republic
and Mexico.
o Working with East and West Builders Club classes.
C.
REFLECTIONS
MAFTTI is well aware of the scope of its task and, after five years’ work and three years after
the Fair Trade Town Declaration, can easily point to areas where more emphasis needs to be
given. These include focusing on the securing of more institutional support for Fair Trade
products in business, civic and service-oriented organizations in order to scale up the impact of
Fair Trade purchasing in the area. Similarly while work on Fair Trade principles within the
school curriculum has been started, there is much more that could be done. Public awareness
of Fair Trade and the issues it presents to Mankato-area consumers also needs to be raised
further from the low base evident a few years ago.
MAFTTI feels, nonetheless, that it has followed the Council’s own maxim in “leading the way”
on Fair Trade both up to and since the Fair Trade Town Declaration. When MAFTTI’s 5
th
Anniversary was marked in June 2014, this message was received from Billy Linstead
Goldsmith, Nation Coordinator of Fair Trade Campaigns:
“Fair Trade Campaigns extends a grateful "Congratulations" to MAFTTI on its five year
anniversary. From driving awareness and demand for Fair Trade products in the Mankato area,
to the fantastic events and collaboration that they have accomplished, the Mankato Area Fair
Trade Town Initiative has been an example for other communities around the country to
follow. The campaign has provided local, regional and national leadership, as well as helped us
pilot and test new initiatives to drive the Fair Trade movement forward. We are thrilled to
continue working with MAFTTI and the wonderful people who are leading the work there for
many more years to come.”
MAFTTI looks forward to further engagement with the City Council in promoting Mankato as
the first Fair Trade Town in Minnesota and finding practical ways of giving such collaboration
expression.
Paul Renshaw
MAFTTI Chair
October 4, 2014

text.i: Leading the Way as a Prosperous Diverse Regional Community

page.text: Motion to waive the rental fees for use Sibley Park for the YWCA of
Mankato Girls on the Run event to be held on April 25, 2015 (In-kind request total =
: Motion approving in-kind request.
The YWCA of Mankato has requested the waiver of fees for use of Sibley Park for a
“Girls on the Run” event to be held on April 25, 2015. According to the in-kind services
policy, this event is considered a “community event” and in-direct costs, such as use
fees, may be waived with Council approval.
None

text.i: Leading the Way as a Prosperous Diverse Regional Community

page.text: : Motion approving on-sale Intoxicating liquor license (Class B), Sunday
liquor, non-enclosed premise (patio), and 2 a.m. closing for M, M, and M, Inc., DBA
Jonny B’s on the Plaza, 12 Civic Center Plaza, Suite 1675, (current location of Mum’s
the Word).
: Council approve application
Application has been submitted by Jon Mueller as owner of Jonny B’s on the Plaza, 12
Civic Center Plaza, Suite 1675 (former Mum’s location), Mankato, for an on-sale
intoxicating liquor, Sunday liquor, and Inclusion of Non-Enclosed Premise license to
commence on November 1, 2014. (Class B - Grandfathered license pre-2007)
Taxes are current for this premise. A liquor license-holder agreement has been
negotiated between the applicant and the Department of Public Safety and signed by
the applicant and the city manager.
A background investigation of all persons and premises named in the application
reveals nothing that would preclude issuance of this license.
A license fee of $3,460 and investigation fee of $500 will be set for deposit into the city’s
general fund.
None

text.i: Leading the Way as a Prosperous Diverse Regional Community

page.text: : Motion authorizing the City Manager to enter into an interagency
agreement with the Minnesota Department of Employment and Economic Development
State Services for the Blind (SSB) division for the purpose of facilitating the Radio
Talking Book (RTB) broadcast for Mankato.
: Approve motion
Pursuant to Minnesota Statute 471.59, Subdivision 10, Minnesota governmental units
may enter into interagency agreements. This agreement is between the City of manakto
and the Minnesota Department of Employment and Economic Development’s State
Services for the Blind (SSB) division, for the purpose of facilitating the Radio Talking
Book (RTB) broadcast from Mankato.
The intent of the parties is to facilitate radio broadcasts of Mankato-area news and
items of interest to be aired over the RTB radio reading service. The parties will be in
close and frequent communication to ensure that the broadcasts can be made and that
the facilities are kept clean and secure.
Interagency Agreement
: Resolution approving premise permit application by the St. Clair Fire
Relief Association to conduct lawful gambling at The Bicker Inn, 100 East Walnut Street.
: Council approve application
The St. Clair Fire Relief Association does not currently have gambling sites within the
City of Mankato. The required bonding and insurance information for this gambling
license has been provided. A background investigation of all persons and premises
described in the application reveal nothing to preclude issuance of the license.
Resolution

text.b: RESOLUTION APPROVING ST. CLAIR FIRE RELIEF ASSOCIATION TO
CONDUCT LAWFUL GAMBLING AT THE BICKER INN

page.text: WHEREAS, Mankato City Code Section 5.43 outlines the regulations
regarding lawful gambling activities, and
WHEREAS, St. Clair Fire Relief Association has submitted the required
applications, and
WHEREAS, a background check of the officers involved in conducting the
activities has been successfully completed, and
WHEREAS, St. Clair Fire Relief Association has complied with all the
requirements of Mankato City Code Section 5.43.
NOW THEREFORE BE IT RESOLVED by the City Council for the City of
Mankato that the Lawful Gambling Premises Permit Application for St. Clair Fire
Relief Association to conduct lawful gambling at The Bicker Inn, 100 East Walnut
Street, Mankato, MN is hereby approved.
BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED by the City Council for the City of Mankato that
the 60-day waiting period is waived.
Adopted this 13
th
day of October 2014.
Eric T. Anderson
Mayor
ATTEST:
Renae Kopischke
Executive Secretary

text.i: Leading the Way as a Prosperous Diverse Regional Community

page.text: : Resolution to accept a bid to purchase a used fire rescue apparatus.
: Council Approval of Resolution to authorize the City Manager
to accept a bid to purchase a used fire rescue apparatus from Brindlee Mountain Fire
Apparatus, LLC in the amount of $145,000.00.
The Department of Public Safety has identified a need to replace an aging rescue
apparatus. The current vehicle is a 1988 Chevrolet Marion that was purchased as a
used vehicle around 1995. The vehicle was utilized by the Mankato/Blue Earth County
volunteer rescue squad to transport people and equipment to technical rescue
emergencies.
In 2006, the volunteer rescue squad disbanded and technical rescue services were
assumed by the Public Safety – fire division. The age of the vehicle combined with
changes in services provided necessitate replacement of the vehicle. A used rescue
apparatus with more functional storage space is sought as a cost-effective solution.
Public Safety has planned for and budgeted for this replacement as part of the
apparatus replacement fund. A used vehicle is being requested with the expectation of
a better return on investment than a new vehicle that would cost in excess of
The request for bids was advertised and bid packets were sent to seven dealers. One
bid was submitted for the public bid opening. It is believed that the reason multiple bids
were not received is because the market for used rescue apparatus specified is small
compared to fire engines or ladder trucks.
Resolution

text.b: RESOLUTION AUTHORIZING THE CITY MANAGER TO ENTER INTO AN
AGREEMENT TO PURCHASE A REPLACEMENT USED RESCUE TRUCK

page.text: WHEREAS, the Mankato Department of Public Safety has determined that the
current rescue truck has surpassed its anticipated lifespan; and
WHEREAS, the cost of replacing this vehicle has been planned for and budgeted
for; and
WHEREAS, the department has requested multiple used vehicle dealerships to
submit bids for used apparatus meeting the current and future needs of the fire rescue
service; and
WHEREAS, one bid has been received, reviewed and City staff recommends
awarding the bid to Brindlee Mountain Fire Apparatus, LLC, the lowest responsible
bidder; and
NOW THEREFORE BE IT RESOLVED by the City Council for the City of
Mankato that the City Manager be and hereby is authorized to execute an agreement with
Brindlee Mountain Fire Apparatus, LLC for the purchase of a used rescue truck for a total
cost not to exceed $145,000.00.
This Resolution shall become effective upon its passage and without further
publication.
Dated this 13
th
day of October 2014.
Eric T. Anderson
Mayor
Renae Kopischke
Executive Secretary

text.i: Leading the Way as a Prosperous Diverse Regional Community

page.text: : Motion approving the Preliminary Plat of Country Club Estates No. 20
with conditions, Outlot A, Country Club Estates No. 19; by request of Hiniker Homes.
: At their September 24, 2014 meeting the Planning
Commission recommended a motion approving the preliminary plat of Country Club
Estates No. 20 with the following conditions:
1. The depicted temporary cul-de-sac at on the extension of Torrey Pines Drive
shall be hardsurfaced and possibly curbed to City standards.
2. An updated and finalized cost estimate, prepared per Engineering guideline
sheet, shall be submitted with the final plat.
3. Sidewalk is required on the north side of Torrey Pines Drive.
4. The maximum sidewalk grade shall be 2%.
5. Construction plans submitted with the final plat shall demonstrate use of
bituminous at traffic level 3.
6. If possible a 2nd connection to public street from Torrey Pines Drive shall be
implemented with the next phase of development.
The applicant, Hiniker Homes, is requesting the preliminary plat review of Country Club
Estates No. 20. The subject property is located to the south of Augusta Drive and
Grovebrook Circle, and to the west of existing Torrey Pines Drive, which will be
extended as part of the development.
The proposed preliminary plat depicts a two-block subdivision with 30 single-family
residential lots, ranging in size from 10,626 square feet to 13,865 square feet. A 15.05
acre outlot (Outlot A) is also depicted, and demonstrates anticipated future development
to the west along extensions of Torrey Pines Drive, Castle Pines Drive, and Bear Path
Drive.
Parcels proposed for the northern side of Torrey Pines Drive extension are impacted by
the existing 83 foot-wide Minnegasco easement, which has been previously recorded.
Other previously-developed parcels in the area are also impacted by the easement.

text.i: Leading the Way as a Prosperous Diverse Regional Community

page.text: : Resolution granting Conditional Use Permit to allow storage units in the
B-3, Highway Commercial District, 1721 Madison Avenue; by request of Amerco Real
Estate/U-Haul Company of Southern Minnesota.
: At their September 24, 2014 meeting the Planning
Commission recommended adoption of the attached resolution.
The applicant, Amerco Real Estate/U-Haul Company of Southern Minnesota, is
requesting a conditional use permit to allow for additional storage facilities at their
existing location at 1721 Madison Avenue, in a B-3, Highway Business District. The
property is legally described as the West 434.68 feet of Lot 1, Block 1, Thro’s
Subdivision.
The proposed additional buildings consist of a 2-story storage building with a footprint of
17,871 square feet and exterior dimensions of 111’ x 161’, and a square single-story
warehouse building with a footprint of 4,994 square feet. The proposed new 2-story
storage building would feature a total of 498 storage units of varying sizes, from 5’x5’ to
10’x15’ units. The proposal also includes 16 ADA-accessible units and an elevator in
the 2-story storage building. Utilities to both buildings will be provided.
The applicants have advised that the new storage facility will be climate-controlled, with
each storage unit being individually alarmed. The facility utilizes around-the-clock
surveillance through a network of 40 high-definition video cameras that is networked to
on-site security staff and company employees via their mobile devices.
The facility also requires use of a special theft/damage resistant disk lock. The hours of
operation are Monday through Thursday, 7AM – 5PM, Friday 7AM – 8PM, Saturday
7AM – 7PM, and Sunday 9AM – 5PM. The applicants have advised that they do not
intend to install any fencing for the proposed additions, due to the advanced internal
security measures they are proposing.
The exterior finish of the 2-story storage building is a mixture of concrete tip-up panels
and shadow rib metal panels, with clear tempered glass windows on the 2
nd
story on the
eastern, northern, and western elevations. The 2-story storage building proposed a flat
roof, and exterior overhead door accesses to larger storage units are included on the
ground floor of the eastern and northern elevations.

text.i: Leading the Way as a Prosperous Diverse Regional Community

page.text: The exterior finish of the warehouse building proposed for the southern portion of the lot
is MBCI metal wall panels, with a standing-seam metal roof. Overhead and exterior
doors are located on the southern and northern elevations.
The proposed landscaping plan depicts necessary setbacks and landscaping plantings.
Trees will need to be planted at minimum current standards of 6’ height for evergreen
trees and 2 ½” caliper for shade trees. Existing trees in the southern portions of the site
will be retained. All areas of the site not utilized for landscaping or required setback
buffers will be hardsurfaced with concrete or asphalt.
An existing platted 40 foot driveway and utility easement on the southwest portion of the
property will not be impacted with the proposal and access to the adjacent property to
the west will be maintained. A 50 foot driveway and utility easement across the
southern portion of the property to the east (U.S. Bank) has also been recorded and will
continue to offer access to the southeast portion of the site via an existing concrete
drive lane which passes through both properties.
Resolution granting Conditional Use Permit
General Location Map
Site Plan
Building Elevations
Landscaping and Paving Plan
A RESOLUTION OF THE CITY COUNCIL
GRANTING A CONDITIONAL USE PERMIT UNDER
THE MANKATO ZONING ORDINANCE
WHEREAS, Amerco Real Estate Company, current owner of the following property, to-
wit:
The West 434.68 feet of Lot 1, Block 1, Thro’s Subdivision (1721 Madison Avenue)
has applied for a conditional use permit to allow storage units in the B-3, Highway Commercial
District.
WHEREAS, the Planning Agency of the City of Mankato has completed a review of the
application and made a report pertaining to said request (CY 50-14), a copy of which has been
presented to the City Council; and
WHEREAS, the Planning Commission of the City, on the 24
th
day of September, 2014,
following proper notice, held a public hearing regarding the request, and following said public
hearing, adopted a recommendation that the request for a conditional use permit be approved;
and
WHEREAS, the minutes of such public hearing and recommendation of the Commission
have been presented to the City Council; and
WHEREAS, based upon the Planning Agency report, minutes and recommendation, the
City Council hereby finds that:
The development plan conforms to the standards of the B-3, Highway Business
District, and other applicable sections of Chapter 10 of the Mankato City Code.
2. The use conforms to the standards for granting a conditional use permit contained in
Section 10.92, Subdivision 5.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED by the Mankato City Council that the
conditional use permit to allow for storage units in the B-3, Highway Business District be
approved subject to the following conditions:
Outdoor storage of materials or items is prohibited.
A lighting plan shall be submitted with the building permit application. All lighting
fixtures shall be of full cut-off design.
Any new exterior signage shall require sign permit prior to fabrication or installation
of signage.
Grading and utility plans shall be submitted for review at time of building permit
submittal.
Resolution – Conditional Use Permit
CY 50-14 U-Haul Storage Units
Page 2 of 2
Finalized landscape plans, depicting plantings per Mankato City Code Section 10.88,
including minimum sizes at time of planting of 6’ height for evergreen trees and 2 ½”
caliper for shade trees, shall be submitted at time of building permit.
The access easement to the adjacent property to the west shall be maintained and kept
clear from obstruction at all times.
All exterior elevations shall adhere to Mankato City Code Section 10.87 pertaining to
franchise architecture (“earth tone color”) regulations.
Security and alarm systems details shall be submitted for review by Department of
Public Safety staff, and any revisions required by Department of Public Safety staff
shall be undertaken accordingly.
All parking and driving areas shall be hardsurfaced with concrete or asphalt.
10. No parking shall occur on any grass areas or areas not hardsurfaced to City standards.
11. Any existing or new proposed exterior waste receptacles shall require a dumpster
enclosure. Alternately, refuse containers may be utilized inside only except at times
when refuse is being collected.
This resolution shall become effective immediately upon its passage and without publication.
Passed this______
Mayor
Executive Secretary

text.i: Leading the Way as a Prosperous Diverse Regional Community

page.text: : Resolution approving Final Plat of Campus Townhomes and Resolution
approving Planned Unit Development, Lot 1, Block 1, University Park Subdivision No. 6
and Outlots C, D, and G, Oak Marsh Subdivision; by request of Growth Holdings, LLC,
and Campus Cottages, LLC.
: At their September 24, 2014 meeting the Planning
Commission recommended adoption of the resolutions.
The applicants are requesting a final plat review of Campus Townhomes, and a
Planned Unit Development for mixed-density housing. The property was previously
reviewed by the Planning Commission as a preliminary plat and land use plan
amendment in April 2014; plat was Oak Marsh Subdivision No. 2. The City Council
approved the request for land use plan amendment to change the designation of 5.03
acres in the southwest corner of Outlot G, Oak Marsh Subdivision from low density
residential to high density residential at their May 27, 2014 meeting.
The proposal is for a mixed-density development. The previously-reviewed preliminary
plat design and plan layout were based on coordination with and feedback from
property owners in adjacent low-density residential areas and private restrictive
covenants were recorded which limited the development to the plan reviewed and
approved at that time. Per the conditions of approval of the preliminary plat, the final
plat was to be submitted concurrently with request for Planned Unit Development. The
rezoning will be considered by the Planning Commission in October and forwarded to
the Council in November.
The final plat depicts a mixed-density development consisting of 35 lots on 5 blocks,
with 34 of the lots being proposed for single family residential purposes on the northern
and eastern portions of the site.
Block 1 of the proposed subdivision contains 13 lots ranging in size from approximately
11,000 square feet to 22,000 square feet. The lots will be utilized for single family
dwelling and will be zoned R-1. These lots will be located to the south of the existing
gas main easement and will be accessed via Oak Marsh Drive.
Block 2 of the proposed subdivision contains 16 lots ranging in size from approximately
8,000 square feet to 18,000 square feet. The lots will be utilized for single family
dwellings and will be zoned R-1. These lots will be located to the south of the existing
gas main easement and will be accessed via Oak Marsh Drive.

text.i: Leading the Way as a Prosperous Diverse Regional Community

page.text: Block 3 of the proposed subdivision contains 3 lots ranging in size from approximately
13,000 square feet to 16,000 square feet. The lots will be utilized for single family
dwelling and will be zoned R-1. These lots will be located to the north of the existing gas
main easement and will be accessed via Oak Marsh Drive.
Block 4 of the proposed subdivision contains 1 lot encompassing 14,400 square feet
and a park area. The lot will be utilized for single family dwelling and will be zoned R-1.
This lot and park area will be located to the north of the existing gas main easement and
will be accessed via Oak Marsh Drive.
Block 5 of the proposed subdivision contains 1 lot encompassing 13.43 acres. The lot
will be developed as a multiple family dwelling complex containing 8 buildings with 181
units and all associated parking and will be zoned R-4. These lots will be located to the
south of the existing gas main easement and will be accessed via Timberwolf Drive.
The preliminary plat plan noted 7 apartment buildings with 147 units. The proposed
increase for Block 5 is one apartment building and a total of 34 additional apartment
units.
Services are available via multiple connections to the site. Services are stubbed on the
southern portion of the lot via Timberwolf Drive, the north from Oak Marsh Drive, and
east from Pohl Road.
The Woodland Preservation Ordinance limits clearing of the wooded areas to not more
than 30%. The proposed development will impact 28.5% of the wooded areas. The
28.5% includes all of the clearing for proposed Oak Marsh Drive and assumes clearing
of all of the trees in the areas depicted as residential lots.
The submitted final plat and revised layout for the multi-family development proposed
for Block 5 contain a number of changes from the preliminary plat which was reviewed
and recommended for approval, and which was reflected in the private restrictive
covenants agreed to by the applicant and adjacent property owners. Most notably, the
revised site plan denotes the following:
1. An additional apartment building upon the proposed high-density portion of the
development on Outlot G, increasing the total number of apartment buildings from 7
to 8.
2. Increase of overall dwelling units from 147 to 181 units.
3. Additional parking areas located in the eastern and northern areas of Outlot G,
located closer to adjacent low-density residential areas than were depicted on the
original plan.
4. Relocation of the community building and facilities from the central portion of the
block to the southwestern portion.
5. The proposed parking area in the center of the site is depicted as being an interior
parking area, surrounded by four buildings, in the updated plan. The original plan
noted three apartment buildings and the community building within the interior of the
site, with parking surrounding.

text.i: Leading the Way as a Prosperous Diverse Regional Community

page.text: The 8 proposed apartment buildings feature the following unit breakdown:
• One 17 unit building
• Two 20 unit buildings
• Three 23 unit buildings
• One 26 unit building
• One 29 unit building
The submitted floor plans denote primarily a mixture of 2 and 3 bedroom units, with 2
four-bedroom units in each building. First-floor plans denote single level units and the
upper 2 floors having up/down two-floor configurations. Floor plans depict living/dining
areas, kitchen facilities, patio/balcony areas, washer/dryers, and a private bathroom for
each bedroom. There are a total of 504 bedrooms associated with the apartment
buildings under the revised plans, versus a total of 510 proposed bedrooms associated
with the initial proposal previously reviewed.
The buildings are 40 feet tall to the peak of the roof, and 30 feet tall to the lower edge of
the roof line. Proposed exterior treatments denotes brick first-floor concourse, and a
mixture of horizontal and vertical siding in noted tan, and forest green colors, with
peaked roof areas in the mid-points of the buildings. Window treatments depict upper-
window portion crosshatch. Most units will feature deck or balcony. However, the
applicant has advised that per an agreement with area residents, the units facing
adjacent residential areas on the eastern and northern sides of the properties will not
feature balcony/patio areas in order to limit noise. Areas without decks/balconies are
outlined in red on the site plan.
The proposed landscape plan complies with City Code requirements and provides
necessary planting along the site perimeter. A blend of evergreen and shade trees are
depicted in areas adjacent to existing and proposed single-family residential areas,
including upon areas proposed for berming on the northeastern and northwestern
areas. Plantings are noted at the required minimum planting heights per City Code
requirements. Revised plans submitted by the applicant denote additional berming in an
effort reduce noise trespass.
Several designs of fencing are proposed for the perimeter of the site. The southern
adjacent to Timberwolf Drive proposes black powder coated aluminum fence at 8’
height, with decorative brick columns.
Areas adjacent to residential properties on Timberwolf Drive on the eastern side of the
site would feature solid brown plastic composite fencing of 8’ height, in addition to
plantings. The remainder of the site would have black powder-coated chain-link fencing
installed at 8’ height.
Proposed parking meets City Code requirements. Based on the required 2 stalls per
unit, 362 stalls are required, and a total of 472 stalls are proposed for the development.
The applicants are in final stages of updating the private restrictive covenants which
reflect the proposed changes. If the project is approved by the City Council, an
updated signed copy of the private covenants documenting approval by all parties of the
original shall be required prior to issuance of any building permits for the development.

text.i: Leading the Way as a Prosperous Diverse Regional Community

page.text: Prior to the Planning Commission meeting, the residents of St. Anthony Townhomes
submitted a letter with questions and comments regarding the proposal. The letter was
reviewed during the Planning Commission meeting and responses were drafted. No
residents besides those on Oak Marsh Drive testified at the Planning Commission
meeting. The residents on Oak Marsh Drive supported the request.
Resolution approving Final Plat
Resolution approving Planned Unit Development
General Location Map
Final Plat
Original approved Layout
Revised Site/Utility Layout
Landscaping Plan
Floor Plans
Exterior Elevations
Copy of Restrictive Covenants
St. Anthony Residents Questions and Responses
Subdivision Agreement
RESOLUTION OF THE MANKATO CITY COUNCIL
APPROVING THE FINAL PLAT OF CAMPUS TOWNHOMES
WHEREAS, Growth Holdings, LLC and Tailwind Oak Marsh, LLC., with permission of
Brookstone Development Group, current owners, have prepared a final plat of Campus Townhomes
Subdivision; and
WHEREAS, the plat (CY 16-14.2) has been referred to the Mankato Planning Commission,
which has reviewed and recommended approval of said plat; and
WHEREAS, the preliminary and final plats conform to the standards set forth in Chapters 10
and 11 of the Mankato City Code; and
WHEREAS, a preliminary plat was reviewed on April 23
rd
, 2014 and recommended for
approval with the following conditions:
1. The applicant shall submit a planned unit development, wetland delineation, and rezoning
request with the final plat.
2. The applicant shall enter into a subdivider's agreement for all public improvement for the
site.
3. Applicant shall submit an access and security plan to Public Safety for review, same as
was done for previous Campus Cottages Development to the south.
4. Stop signs shall be installed on Oak Marsh at Pohl Road intersection.
5. Applicant shall submit civil plans to City Engineering Department for review and
comment.
6. Deferred assessments on the northern lot for the pond are to be paid by the applicant
prior to affixing signatures to the final plat.
7. Sidewalks shall be located on the east and north sides of Oak Marsh Drive.
WHEREAS, it is found that the final plat complies with the preliminary plat intent as
recommended.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED that the Council of the City of Mankato hereby
approves the final plat of Campus Townhomes and authorizes the Mayor and Executive Secretary to
sign said plat and furthermore authorizes the City Manager to enter into a Subdivision Agreement
with the developer.
This resolution shall become effective immediately upon its passage and without publication.
Mayor
Executive Secretary
